Files and General Programming Style

Naming

  • Files should be named using these extensions:
File Type Ext.
C++ Source .cpp
C++ Header .h
  • For C++ Source and C++ Header files:
    • All file names are lower case.

Organization

Files should contain information in this order:

  • Block comment with the license: 
/*
    Copyright (C) 2007 Development Team of Peragro Tempus

    This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
    it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
    the Free Software Foundation; either version 2 of the License, or
    (at your option) any later version.

    This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
    but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
    MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
    GNU General Public License for more details.

    You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
    along with this program; if not, write to the Free Software
    Foundation, Inc., 59 Temple Place, Suite 330, Boston, MA  02111-1307  USA
 */
  • Block, Doxygen-style comment describing the file: 
/**
 * @file somemanager.h
 *
 * @brief Declaration of the Some Manager, which stores information about
 * some things.
 */

No mentioning of @author ... !

  • For C++ headers, each file should contain an include-guard
    • In the event of collisions, additional information may be inserted.
    • Don't use _ or __ for the first characters, they are reserved for language extensions and compiler internals. 
#ifndef FILENAME_H
#define FILENAME_H
...
#endif // FILENAME_H


  • #includes
    • For source files, the corresponding header file (e.g., fooboy.h in fooboy.cpp
    • C / C++ Standard headers <iostream>, <string>, <vector>, etc.)
    • CrystalSpace headers
    • CEL headers
    • External lib headers (e.g., CEGUI)
    • Peragro Tempus-specific headers
  • Type declarations (e.g., forward declarations, typedefs
  • File-wide constants
  • File-wide / global variables (should be avoided where possible)
  • Class declarations (generally, header files only)
  • Class function definitions (generally, source files only, except for one-line functions defined in-class)

Namespaces

  • All code should be in the PT namespace.

Indentation and Line Width

General, file-wide requirements for indentation. Please refer to the sections specific to each construct for specific indentation information.

  • All preprocessor directives are flush with the left margin. (NOTE: This is a C++ restriction, so don't try to break it)
  • The indentation width is set at 2 characters.
  • Never use tab! (Convert it to 2 spaces.)
  • Lines should be a maximum of 80 characters in width. Note that this is not a hard-and-fast rule - bending it is fine, but lines that require horizontal scrolling are too long and should be broken up. And no, just because your console can display 197,000 characters without scrolling doesn't mean that everyone else's does too.

Control and Looping Structures

All control and looping structures

  • All loop / control structures should have their bodies surrounded by curly braces, even when they only contain a single statement. This makes for easier modification in the future - the maintainer does not have to note whether the curly braces should be added or not when adding new instructions to the body.
  • The opening curly brace should be on its own line.
  • Following the closing curly brace, a comment should be written to note what kind of structure was just finished. In complex code, this sometimes helps to visually note which braces go with which structure. If nothing else, it helps the coder focus on what s/he is writing as he types out code in a mad frenzy.
  • Follow the same formatting as function calls; each control or looping structure should have a space between the keyword and the opening parenthesis. 
if (foo == true)             // Notice the space
for(int i = 0; i != 10; ++i) // BAD - no space between the for and the '('
  • The body of a control structure should be indented with 2 spaces.

if statements 

if (foo == true)
{
  doSomething();
} // end if

for statements 

for (int i = 0; i != 10; ++i)
{
  std::cout << "i = " << i << std::endl;
} // end for

switch statements

  • switch statements should always have a default clause.
  • If a case conditional within a switch statement falls through to the next case, then a comment explaining this should be written in place of the break statement. 
switch (var)
{
  case 0:
    do(something);
    // Falls through to case 1.
  case 1:
  {
    int foo = bar();
    do(something, foo);
    break;
  }
  default:
    bleh();
} // end switch

do / while statements

  • The while follows on the same line as the closing curly brace.
  • Since the while occurs where the end-of-structure comment normally would, the comment can be omitted. 
do
{
  something(foo);
  foo = foo->next;
} while (foo != 0);

Variables

Naming

  • Variables are named with the first letter lowercase and the first letter of subsequent words capitalized.
    • int rateOfVarName;
    • float coolDownPeriod;
  • One-letter variables are not allowed, except to indicate throwaway values.
    • int r; // r => rateOfFire - don't do this.
    • for (int i = 0; i != 10; ++i); // This works.
  • Global consts (e.g., magic values, EOF, etc.) are named in all caps with underscores separating the words.
    • const int MAGIC_VALUE = 5;
    • const float MAX_SPEED = 10000.0f;
  • Hungarian notation is strongly discouraged. All of the following are verboten:
    • int iSpeed;}}}
    • float fLength;}}}
    • SuperDuperClass sdcInstance;

Declaration and Usage

  • Pointer and reference variables are declared with the * or & next to the type name.
    • float* pokey;
    • const int& varRef;
    • const int* ohBoy;
    • Exception: When declaring a const pointer (not a pointer to a const), the * is by itself. (Naming for demonstrative puproses only)
      • int const * constIntPtr;
      • const float const * constFloatPtrToAFloat;
  • If the variable is a float, rather than a double, then assign values to it with the 'f' suffix. This eliminates the conversion from double (the default under many compilers) to a float.
    • float f = 1.0f; // Notice the 'f' as the suffix - forces the compiler to treat 1.0 as a float.
    • double d = 1.0; // On some compilers, the 1.0 defaults to a double, rather than a float
  • Follow the Principle of Least Privilege - only give the variable the amount of power it needs to function
    • If the variable will not be modified, declare it const.
      • const noTouchee;
    • If a static variable of a class is only going to be referenced in one function, make it a static local variable within that function, rather than a static variable within the class.
    • If a variable is not going to be modified through a pointer, then declare the pointer to be a pointer to a const.

Functions

Naming

  • All functions should be named with the first letter capitalized and all subsequent words capitalized.
    • int FooBar();
  • Parameters should be named in the same fashion as regular variables.
    • Exception: const parameters should be named as regular variables, rather than in ALL_CAPS.
    • float CalculateSpeed(float distTraveled, float time);

Usage

  • Functions are internally indented 2 spaces.
  • The opening brace for the function should be on its own line.
  • The closing brace for the function should be followed by a comment providing the name of the function that was just finished. 
float CalcSpeed(float distTraveled, float time)
{
  return distTraveled / time;
} // end CalcSpeed()

Classes, Structures, and other Complex Data Types

  • Class / struct ("class") names begin with a capital letter and the first letter of subsequent words capitalized.
    • class FooBoy {};
    • struct DataHolder {};
  • The layout of the visibility of class members is as follows:
    • public
    • protected
    • private
  • Within each visibility, the layout of members is as follows:
    • Nested types (e.g., nested classes / structs, enums, and typedefs)
    • Static variables
    • Instance variables
    • Static functions
    • Member functions
  • These rules may be overridden to put public nested types before they are requested in the class

Other data types

  • Typedefs and enums follow the same naming rule as classes
    • typedef int Health;
    • enum MyEnum {};
  • Enum values follow the same naming scheme as global consts
  • Enum values should be on separate lines 
enum KeyPresses
{
  UP_ARROW,
  DOWN_ARROW,
  LEFT_ARROW,
  RIGHT_ARROW
};
